column1:
Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6].
In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].
column2: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
column4: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
column5:
[PASS] (1.00)

Genetic studies have been instrumental in identifying the genetic basis of complex traits and diseases. However, the functional interpretation of these associations remains a significant challenge. This manuscript presents a novel approach to project genetic associations through gene expression patterns, thereby highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms. By integrating genetic studies with functional genomics, we aim to elucidate the role of gene co-expression in the clustering of complex traits. This approach not only provides insights into the therapeutic targets but also paves the way for drug repurposing.

Reason: All assertions passed
column6:
[PASS] (1.00)

Genetic studies have significantly advanced our understanding of complex traits and diseases, yet the functional interpretation of genetic associations remains a challenge (1,2). The integration of functional genomics data, such as gene co-expression patterns, can provide valuable insights into the biological mechanisms underlying these associations (3,4). However, current methods for projecting genetic associations onto gene expression patterns often overlook the clustering of complex traits, which can lead to incomplete or misleading interpretations (5,6). This gap in our understanding hinders the identification of therapeutic targets and the repurposing of existing drugs. Our manuscript addresses this issue by developing a novel approach that incorporates the clustering of complex traits into the projection of genetic associations. We demonstrate the utility of our approach by highlighting the etiology of various diseases and the mechanisms of several drugs, thereby providing a new perspective on the functional interpretation of genetic studies.

Reason: All assertions passed
